intro: Athamanta libanotis var. exaltata, commonly known as the Lebanon bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of the Eastern Mediterranean. It is characterized by its tall, erect stems and clusters of bell-shaped, blue to violet flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant has lance-shaped leaves that are typically covered in fine hairs, giving it a slightly rough texture. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it a popular choice for rock gardens and alpine settings. Due to its ornamental value and ecological significance, it is often cultivated in botanical gardens and conservation programs.
